keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was sentenced to a prison term ranging from five years to life after being convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 by claiming he had died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which led to a false obituary, and fled the U.S., using multiple aliases including Arthur Knight.
He was identified through a DNA match from a decade-old rape kit, and later arrested in Scotland in 2021 after hospital staff recognized his tattoos from an Interpol notice.
Rossi used multiple aliases and evaded capture for years, including a prior conviction in Ohio for sex-related offenses and failure to register as a sex offender in Rhode Island.
The victim testified that Rossi coerced her into financial obligations, engaged in abusive behavior, and raped her after their relationship began, which she reported years later.
A Utah judge described Rossi as a 'serial abuser of women' and a 'flight risk,' emphasizing the danger he posed to community safety.
The case highlights the importance of clearing rape kit backlogs and using DNA technology to identify and prosecute offenders who evade justice.
This case is significant because it demonstrates how long-term evasion and fabricated death can be used to avoid accountability, and how public systems can ultimately catch such individuals.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah man named Nicholas Rossi, who used the alias Arthur Knight and faked his death in 2020 to evade arrest, was sentenced to a prison term ranging from five years to life after being convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. The case emerged from a decade-old DNA rape kit backlog, where his identity was traced through tattoos and an Interpol notice. After being arrested in Scotland in 2021 and extradited to Utah in 2024, Rossi maintained his innocence and claimed he was being framed. Jurors found him guilty based on testimony from the victims, who described coercive financial demands and violent rape. The judge described Rossi as a 'serial abuser' and a 'flight risk,' emphasizing public safety concerns. The case underscores the dangers of flight and deception in sexual crimes and highlights the importance of DNA databases and cross-jurisdictional law enforcement cooperation.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
